Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Processing, Interpretation and Dissemination of the Proof-of-Concept Transient Electromagnetic Survey of the McMurdo Dry Valleys Region
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
The MCM-SkyTEM project mapped resistivity in the McMurdo Dry Valleys and at Cape Barne on the Ross Island during the 2011-12 austral season using an airborne transient electromagnetic method. The SkyTEM system is mounted to a helicopter enabling a broad geophysical survey of subsurface resistivity structure over terrain that is inaccessible to traditional ground-based methods. Resistivity measurements obtained distinguish between highly resistive geologic materials such as glacier ice, bedrock and permafrost, and conductive materials such as unfrozen sediments or permafrost with liquid brine to depths of about 300 m. The PIs request funding to derive data products relevant to physical and chemical conditions in potential subsurface microbial habitats of the McMurdo Dry Valleys, similar cold regions on Earth and other planetary bodies. They will use these data products to characterize the hydrologic history of McMurdo Dry Valleys as well as the subsurface hydrologic connectivity in the region to investigate the implications for nutrient and microbial transport. The PIs will make these data products accessible to the research community.

Broader impacts:
Polar microbial habitats are of high societal and scientific interest because they represent important testing grounds for the limits of life on Earth and other planetary bodies. Project deliverables will include teaching aids for undergraduate and graduate students. Two Ph.D. students will obtain advanced research training as part of this project. The PIs and students on this project will also engage in informal public outreach opportunities by presenting at local K-12 schools and reaching out to local media outlets on stories relating to SkyTEM research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Antarctic subsurface environment is among the most difficult ecosystems in the world to access because most of it is covered by glaciers and the ice sheet which may hold 100s-1000s of meters of ice. Along the coastal margins of Antarctica, land is exposed, and classified as permafrost (soil frozen for two or more consecutive years), which can be relatively shallow (starting at around 20 cm depth) and thick extending deep below the surface (greater than 100 meters). Microbial life in both ice covered and permafrost subsurface environments have remained largely unexplored. In recent decades, airborne geophysical surveys and satellite observations have revealed the presence of extensive unfrozen saturated sediments and hundreds of lakes deep below the Antarctic ice sheet. Exceedingly few of these environments have been sampled, however, all have contained viable microorganisms. Still, much remains unknown about the Antarctic world beneath the ice and in particular, the deep subsurface. While groundwater is known to exist on all other continents and is an important resource, little is known about its presence in Antarctica, which would have significant implications for the generation and transport of subsurface nutrients from the continent and their delivery into the surrounding Southern Ocean.

We used an airborne transient electromagnetic (AEM) sensor for the first time in Antarctica to produce extensive imagery of the resistivity of materials beneath Taylor Valley in the McMurdo Dry Valleys (MDV). The resistivity profile extending deep beneath the surface allows the identification of frozen and unfrozen layers and those that have high levels of salts and water (brines). The AEM results revealed areas of low subsurface resistivity under glaciers and lakes and deep below (greater than 100 m) permafrost, which was in contrast to the high resistivity of glacier ice or dry and frozen permafrost present throughout this region. These low resistivity features are consistent with the presence of cold brines and lead us to conclude that extensive groundwater exists below some of the glaciers, lakes and permafrost. As part of this EAGER project, data collected from the AEM survey was analyzed to explore new research questions around where these saline subsurface environments occur, their possible sources and to hypothesize how these subsurface features may contribute to what happens at the surface, such as the delivery of limiting nutrients in support of photosynthetic production.

Previous studies and current analyses of Blood Falls, a unique place where these deep brines reach the surface, indicate that diverse, metabolically active microbial life exists in the brines beneath the Taylor Glacier. A detailed physiological and genomic analysis of a bacterial isolate from the brine revealed numerous adaptations for cold and salt tolerance, and we detected the first evidence of archaeal populations and confirmed the existence of diverse bacterial populations. Many of the abundant taxa detected were similar to taxonomic groups found in other deep groundwater systems and were distinct from microbial communities found in the MDV surface environments. The metabolic activity of the microbes within the brine is thought to be responsible, in part, for the liberation of high concentrations of dissolved iron and silica from the subglacial bedrock. Sites where subglacial fluids are released may episodically benefit from receiving a pulse of these often limiting nutrients.

Our findings show for the first time that deep, extensive groundwater exists in the polar desert of the MDV. Polar microbial habitats are of high societal and scientific interest because they represent one of the most important testing grounds for the limits of life on Earth and other planetary bodies. We harnessed this public interest to share our findings through informal public outreach discussions and presentations at local K-12 schools and community centers as well as more broadly in the news media. Our findings were featured in several online news outlets and national and international radio programs. This project also supported the training of undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral researchers.
